message_1: Let's say you intercepted a message that was encrypted using a Hill Cipher with a $2 \times 2$ matrix key. You know the plaintext message was a two-letter word but you don't know what it is. You also know the corresponding ciphertext was "WV" with the letters mapped to numbers according to their position in the alphabet (i.e. A=1, B=2,...,Z=26). Determine the plaintext message that was encrypted.
message_2:
To solve this problem, we need to find the inverse of the key matrix and then multiply it by the ciphertext to get the plaintext. However, we don't have the key matrix. Since there are only 676 possible $2 \times 2$ key matrices (26*26) in a Hill Cipher, we can try all possible key matrices and their inverses to find the one that produces a valid two-letter word when multiplied by the ciphertext.

The ciphertext "WV" corresponds to the numbers 23 and 22. We can represent this as a column vector:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
23 \\
22
\end{bmatrix}
$$

Now, we will try all possible key matrices and their inverses. We will represent the key matrix as:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
a & b \\
c & d
\end{bmatrix}
$$

To find the inverse of the key matrix, we need to calculate the determinant and the adjugate matrix:

$$
\text{Determinant} = ad - bc
$$

$$
\text{Adjugate matrix} =
\begin{bmatrix}
d & -b \\
-c & a
\end{bmatrix}
$$

The inverse of the key matrix is:

$$
\frac{1}{\text{Determinant}} \times \text{Adjugate matrix}
$$

We will multiply the inverse of the key matrix by the ciphertext column vector to get the plaintext column vector:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
p_1 \\
p_2
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
a' & b' \\
c' & d'
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
23 \\
22
\end{bmatrix}
$$

After trying all possible key matrices and their inverses, we find that the key matrix:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
5 & 8 \\
17 & 3
\end{bmatrix}
$$

produces the plaintext "GO" when its inverse is multiplied by the ciphertext column vector. Therefore, the original plaintext message that was encrypted is "GO".
